dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: ...so this idea of having two jobs, it's really compelling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...so this idea of having two jobs, it's really compelling.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like Job No. 1 is all about being other-centered, right? Asking 'how can I be most helpful?'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like Job No. one is all about being other-centered, right? Asking 'how can I be most helpful?'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 1 forces you to value relationships and be other-centered. How can I be most helpful? becomes the core of your actions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And that mindset, um, actually makes you more valuable in your actual paid role.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And that mindset, um, actually makes you more valuable in your actual paid role.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: You constantly look for new ways to add value, and in the process, you become much more useful to the people around you. Job no. 1 makes you much better at job no. 2.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's Job No. 2—that's the one that pays the bills, feeds your family.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there's Job No. two-that's the one that pays the bills, feeds your family.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 2 is how you get paid, feed your family, and pursue the agenda of the people who hired you.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and some people get so caught up in helping others they neglect their own responsibilities. Like calling about a lost cat instead of preparing for a meeting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and some people get so caught up in helping others they neglect their own responsibilities. Like calling about a lost cat instead of preparing for a meeting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead of organizing that critical meeting, they end up spending all morning calling neighbors to see if anyone spotted the lost cat that may - or may not - have been wandering on the edge of their neighborhood.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's such a good point. You gotta balance both, not just be helpful to the point of being hopeless.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's such a good point. You gotta balance both, not just be helpful to the point of being hopeless.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: You want to be helpful, but not hopeless. This is why it is so critical to understand that you have two jobs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the key insight here is that Job No. 1 doesn't compete with Job No. 2—it actually makes you better at it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the key insight here is that Job No. one doesn't compete with Job No. two-it actually makes you better at it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 1 does not compete with job no. 2. Job no. 1 makes you much better at job no. 2.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It builds relationships, connects you to strangers... it's like a long-term investment in your network and your character.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It builds relationships, connects you to strangers... it's like a long-term investment in your network and your character.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It builds stronger relationships. It connects you more strongly to others.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But only if you take it seriously as its own thing, not just helping people who can immediately help you back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But only if you take it seriously as its own thing, not just helping people who can immediately help you back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If you only help people who can help you in job no. 2, you will soon be revealed as a superficial and somewhat manipulative person.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh for sure. Otherwise you come across as transactional, like that person who only returns your calls when they need something.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh for sure. Otherwise you come across as transactional, like that person who only returns your calls when they need something.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: You know the type... someone who is eager to help you when you have a big job, but who won't return your phone calls when you are looking for a job.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, don't be that person. Bruce Kasanoff really emphasizes taking pride in both roles equally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, don't be that person. Bruce Kasanoff really emphasizes taking pride in both roles equally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Take equal pride in both jobs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Even making to-do lists for both jobs, analyzing your performance in each...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even making to-do lists for both jobs, analyzing your performance in each...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If you are a to-do list person, make to-do lists for both jobs. At the end of each week, month, and year analyze your performance and achievements in both positions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Because success isn't just financial. Some actions feed your soul, enrich your community...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because success isn't just financial. Some actions feed your soul, enrich your community...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Not every reward is financial. Some actions feed your soul, enrich your community, and model the sort of behaviors you want your peers, friends, and family members to emulate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's a much broader way to think about why we're here, what we're doing with our careers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a much broader way to think about why we're here, what we're doing with our careers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It's not enough to succeed at the job that pays your bills. That is simply too narrow a vision of the reason you are here on Earth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally shifts your perspective from just climbing the ladder to actually adding value everywhere you can.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally shifts your perspective from just climbing the ladder to actually adding value everywhere you can.

HostA: Exactly. And that mindset, um, actually makes you more valuable in your actual paid role.
HostB: But then there's Job No. 2—that’s the one that pays the bills, feeds your family.
HostA: Right, and some people get so caught up in helping others they neglect their own responsibilities. Like calling about a lost cat instead of preparing for a meeting.
HostB: That's such a good point. You gotta balance both, not just be helpful to the point of being hopeless.
HostA: And the key insight here is that Job No. 1 doesn't compete with Job No. 2—it actually makes you better at it.
HostB: It builds relationships, connects you to strangers... it’s like a long-term investment in your network and your character.
HostA: But only if you take it seriously as its own thing, not just helping people who can immediately help you back.
HostB: Oh for sure. Otherwise you come across as transactional, like that person who only returns your calls when they need something.
HostA: Yeah, don’t be that person. Bruce Kasanoff really emphasizes taking pride in both roles equally.
HostB: Even making to-do lists for both jobs, analyzing your performance in each...
HostA: Because success isn't just financial. Some actions feed your soul, enrich your community...
HostB: It’s a much broader way to think about why we're here, what we're doing with our careers.
HostA: Totally shifts your perspective from just climbing the ladder to actually adding value everywhere you can.
